explanation: Acceleration tells you how quickly speed is changing.
Force = mass × acceleration. More mass or more speed-up means more force.
Light moves faster than anything else—nothing beats it.
Friction slows things down when they rub together.
Weight is gravity acting on mass: more mass = more weight.
Density = mass divided by volume.
Floating happens because water pushes up on objects.
Sound is a wave that travels through matter like air or water.
Sometimes light acts like a wave, sometimes like a particle.
Electric current is moving charge, like electrons in a wire.
A capacitor stores energy by holding electric charge.
A magnet or a moving charge makes a magnetic field around it.
Changing magnetic fields can produce electricity.
SHM means something moves in a repeating cycle, like a spring.
Pressure = Force ÷ Area. Smaller areas = more pressure.
Objects stop speeding up when air drag matches gravity.
Light changes direction when it moves between materials.
Diffraction happens when waves go through gaps or around edges.
Waves can add up to make a bigger wave if they match.
Waves meeting out of sync can cancel each other.
Like gravity, electric fields can store energy in positions.
More power means energy is used faster.
Momentum = mass × velocity. Bigger or faster things have more.
Impulse is force × time, and it changes momentum.
Torque causes rotation and depends on how far the force is from the pivot.
Acceleration tells you how quickly speed is changing.
Force = mass × acceleration. More mass or more speed-up means more force.
Light moves faster than anything else—nothing beats it.
Friction slows things down when they rub together.
Weight is gravity acting on mass: more mass = more weight.

Waves meeting out of sync can cancel each other.

Objects stop speeding up when air drag matches gravity.

Waves can add up to make a bigger wave if they match.
Waves meeting out of sync can cancel each other.
Like gravity, electric fields can store energy in positions.
More power means energy is used faster.
Momentum = mass × velocity. Bigger or faster things have more.
Impulse is force × time, and it changes momentum.
Torque causes rotation and depends on how far the force is from the pivot.
In a system with no outside forces, the total momentum stays the same, even if objects inside the system bounce off each other.
Kinetic energy is motion energy. If something is heavier or faster, it has more of it.
Gravity gives things energy when you lift them. The higher they are, the more energy they have.
Ohm’s Law says current increases if voltage goes up, assuming resistance stays the same.
Entropy is disorder. In a closed system, it always increases or stays the same.
When something falls with gravity and *only* gravity acting on it. So, no air resistance or engines.
Think throwing a ball. Horizontally it keeps going, vertically it rises then falls because of gravity.
This is the force that the ground uses to push up on you so you don’t fall through.
When a rope or string pulls on something, it creates tension. Everyone feels the same tension through the rope.
The more you stretch or squish a spring, the harder it pulls back. F = -kx.
Going in a circle? There must be a force pulling toward the center.
Even at constant speed, going in a circle means you're constantly accelerating—because your direction’s always changing.
For every action, there’s an equal and opposite reaction. You push on a wall—it pushes back.
If you do work on something, its energy changes. So pushing = more kinetic energy.
Energy can’t be created or destroyed—just changes form.
This is the sum of kinetic + potential energy. It stays constant if there’s no friction or external work.
Any two objects with mass attract each other. Even you and your phone.
Like charges repel, opposites attract. Comes in positive and negative.
This is how a charge 'reaches out' to affect other charges around it.
Think of it like electric pressure. Higher voltage = more push for charges to move.
Acceleration tells you how quickly speed is changing.
Force = mass × acceleration. More mass or more speed-up means more force.
Light moves faster than anything else—nothing beats it.
Friction slows things down when they rub together.
Weight is gravity acting on mass: more mass = more weight.
Density = mass divided by volume.

Sometimes light acts like a wave, sometimes like a particle.

Changing magnetic fields can produce electricity.

Objects stop speeding up when air drag matches gravity.
Light changes direction when it moves between materials.

Waves meeting out of sync can cancel each other.

Torque causes rotation and depends on how far the force is from the pivot.

Kinetic energy is motion energy. If something is heavier or faster, it has more of it.
Gravity gives things energy when you lift them. The higher they are, the more energy they have.
Ohm’s Law says current increases if voltage goes up, assuming resistance stays the same.
Entropy is disorder. In a closed system, it always increases or stays the same.
When something falls with gravity and *only* gravity acting on it. So, no air resistance or engines.
Think throwing a ball. Horizontally it keeps going, vertically it rises then falls because of gravity.
This is the force that the ground uses to push up on you so you don’t fall through.
When a rope or string pulls on something, it creates tension. Everyone feels the same tension through the rope.
The more you stretch or squish a spring, the harder it pulls back. F = -kx.
Going in a circle? There must be a force pulling toward the center.
Even at constant speed, going in a circle means you're constantly accelerating—because your direction’s always changing.
For every action, there’s an equal and opposite reaction. You push on a wall—it pushes back.
If you do work on something, its energy changes. So pushing = more kinetic energy.
Energy can’t be created or destroyed—just changes form.
This is the sum of kinetic + potential energy. It stays constant if there’s no friction or external work.
Any two objects with mass attract each other. Even you and your phone.
Like charges repel, opposites attract. Comes in positive and negative.
This is how a charge 'reaches out' to affect other charges around it.
Think of it like electric pressure. Higher voltage = more push for charges to move.
Current is the flow of electric charge. It's what powers devices.
This is what makes it harder for current to flow. Wires, resistors, even your body.
In series, everything is one path. In parallel, current can split.
For magnetism: fingers in current direction, curl them, thumb points in magnetic field direction.
Changing magnetic fields = electricity. That’s how generators work.
If a magnet moves near a coil, the coil gets current that fights the change.
The direction of induced current opposes the change that caused it.
They swing with constant back-and-forth motion, and their period depends on length—not mass!
These move energy without moving matter long distances. Think sound, water waves.
This is wave height—higher amplitude = more energy.
How often a wave cycles per second. High frequency = short wavelength.
The time for one full wave cycle. It’s the inverse of frequency.
That high-pitch siren sound coming toward you? Lower when it passes? That’s Doppler.
Waves trapped between boundaries create repeating patterns—like guitar strings or microwave hot spots.
In a perfectly elastic collision, objects bounce off each other and both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved. Think pool balls or ideal physics simulations.
Here, objects stick together or lose some kinetic energy. Momentum is still conserved, but some energy turns into heat or deformation.
This is the average position of mass in an object or system. If you threw something in the air and watched it spin, its center of mass would follow a parabolic path.
Also called moment of inertia, it tells you how hard it is to spin something. More mass far from the axis = harder to spin.
It’s like momentum, but for spinning. Bigger radius or faster spin means more angular momentum—and it’s conserved unless a torque acts.
That high-pitch siren sound coming toward you? Lower when it passes? That’s Doppler.
Waves trapped between boundaries create repeating patterns—like guitar strings or microwave hot spots.
If all the forces on an object cancel out, the net force is zero—which means no acceleration. Don’t confuse movement with net force!
When the net force on an object is zero, it's in equilibrium. That includes constant velocity *or* staying still—basically no acceleration.
An object will stay at rest or move in a straight line at constant speed unless something unbalanced pushes or pulls on it.
Inertia is an object's resistance to changes in motion. More mass = more inertia = harder to speed up, slow down, or turn.
Draw ALL the forces acting on an object. Arrows show direction and size. These help more than you'd think—use them even if not required.
This is the surface pushing up on you so you don’t fall through. It’s not always equal to your weight—depends on the situation.
This is what you 'feel' as your weight, aka the normal force. It can be more or less than mg depending on acceleration.
F = ma. The bigger the force, the more acceleration. The more mass, the less acceleration you get from the same force.
Forces that happen from direct touching—like tension, normal force, friction. If two things touch, there’s at least one.
Forces that act at a distance—like gravity, electric, or magnetic. They don’t need touching to work.
Every force has an equal and opposite reaction. Always. If object A pushes on B, then B pushes back on A equally hard.
The two forces in Newton’s Third Law. They act on different objects but are always equal in size and opposite in direction.
All forces and torques balance, and the object isn’t moving. Classic example: a book sitting still on a table.
Forces are balanced, but the object is moving at constant velocity. No net force doesn’t mean no motion!
Mass is how much stuff you have. Weight is the force of gravity pulling on it. On the moon, your mass stays the same but your weight changes.
Friction always resists the direction of intended relative motion, not necessarily movement. It can actually point forward—like when you walk.
This is a value that tells you how grippy two surfaces are. Higher = more friction.
Static friction keeps things from starting to slide. Kinetic friction slows things down while they’re already sliding.
On a ramp, split gravity into parts: one down the ramp (causes sliding) and one into the ramp (affects normal force).
If a pulley is massless and frictionless, tension stays constant throughout the rope. This simplifies Atwood machines.
Acceleration always points in the direction of the net force, even if the object is moving the other way!
The speed at which drag force cancels out weight, so the object stops accelerating during free fall.
Drag opposes motion through a fluid like air or water, and it increases with speed.
When a spring hangs at rest, the upward spring force exactly balances the downward weight.
The 'k' in Hooke’s Law. A stiffer spring has a higher k, meaning it takes more force to stretch or compress it.
This law says spring force is proportional to how much it’s stretched or compressed. The formula is F = -kx. Negative sign = it pulls back toward equilibrium.
Any force that brings a system back to equilibrium. In springs, it’s what pulls you back when you stretch it.
Repeated motion back and forth around a center point. Could be a pendulum, spring, or any system with restoring force.
The time it takes to complete one full cycle. If a spring bounces up and down once every 2 seconds, that’s the period.
How many cycles happen per second. Measured in hertz. More bounces per second = higher frequency.
This is how far from equilibrium the motion goes. Bigger amplitude = more energy.
Acceleration toward the center of a circular path. Always present in circular motion, even at constant speed.
In circular motion, velocity points tangent to the path—not toward the center!
The minimum speed needed to stay on a curved path, like at the top of a roller coaster loop. Below it, you fall off.
A sloped curve that lets you turn without needing friction. Think NASCAR or highway exits.
A frame that’s accelerating. In these frames, objects *appear* to move without real forces acting on them.
A non-accelerating frame of reference. Newton’s laws only work without weird adjustments in these frames.
Motion is measured based on your frame of reference. You can be still on a train but moving relative to the ground.
When combining forces or velocities, you need direction and magnitude. Use tip-to-tail or components.
Break a force at an angle into x and y parts. This makes writing equations way easier.
Going in a circle at constant speed. Speed’s constant, but velocity (and acceleration) still change because of direction.
When speed or direction (or both) change over time. Almost everything in the real world does this.
The velocity at one specific moment. Not an average—like checking your speedometer *right now*.
Change in velocity divided by time. It smooths out motion to give one clean value.
When acceleration doesn’t change over time. It’s the key condition for using the kinematic equations!
The highest point in a projectile’s path—when vertical velocity is 0 for a split second.
How far a projectile goes horizontally. Depends on launch angle, speed, and gravity.
Projectile motion is symmetric—time to rise = time to fall (if it starts and ends at the same height).
These equations describe motion with constant acceleration. Always start with what you know and pick the equation that fits.
Distance = total path. Displacement = net change in position. You can have big distance and zero displacement.
Work is done when a force moves something through a distance. No movement = no work, even if you’re pushing hard!
Work = Force × distance × cos(θ). The angle matters! Only the force in the direction of motion counts.
If a force helps motion, work is positive. If it fights motion, work is negative. Think pushing vs resisting.
Power is how fast work is done. More power = same work in less time. Measured in watts.
Energy can’t be created or destroyed—just transferred or transformed. The total stays constant if no outside forces do work.
This is the sum of kinetic and potential energy. It stays constant in ideal systems (no friction or outside work).
Energy stored based on height. More height = more potential to fall and gain speed.
Energy stored in stretched or compressed springs. Depends on the spring constant and how far it's displaced.
This is often 'lost' energy in physics problems—it’s where friction or drag puts the energy.
Efficiency = useful energy out ÷ total energy in. Real machines always have losses—efficiency < 100%.
If no external force acts, momentum stays the same before and after a collision—even if objects bounce or stick.
Both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved. Think ideal bouncy ball or air hockey puck.
Momentum is conserved, but kinetic energy isn’t. Some energy becomes heat, sound, etc.
This is when objects stick together after colliding. Momentum’s still conserved, but they move as one after.
Impulse = change in momentum. You can also get it from force × time. Longer contact time = smaller force needed.
Impulse causes momentum change. Use this when you have time and force instead of just speeds.
When something launches something else, like a gun firing a bullet, both objects feel equal and opposite momentum.
A pulling force from a rope, string, or cable. Tension’s the same throughout if the rope is light and there’s no friction.
A force that causes rotation. Depends on how hard you push *and* how far from the pivot you push.
Torque = r × F × sin(θ). Maximum torque happens when you push perpendicular to the lever arm.
If all the torques cancel out, there’s no angular acceleration. The object doesn’t spin faster or slower.
The average location of mass in an object. It’s where you balance something if you want it to stay level.
The distance from the pivot point to where the force is applied. Longer = more torque for the same force.
This is like regular inertia, but for spinning. More mass, or mass farther from the axis = harder to spin.
Momentum, but for rotation. It’s conserved if no external torques act. Think figure skaters pulling in their arms.
It’s the energy of spinning motion. KE_rot = ½ Iω². Like linear KE, but for stuff that’s rotating.
It’s like mass, but for rotation. Depends on how the mass is distributed around the axis.
When a wheel rolls and the bottom point doesn’t slide. Velocity at the bottom = 0 at each moment.
Translational = moving from one spot to another. Rotational = spinning. Objects can do both at once.
Basically the point where gravity ‘acts.’ For uniform objects, it’s the same as the center of mass.
This is gravity’s version of an electric field. It shows the strength and direction of gravitational force per unit mass.
Every mass pulls on every other mass. F = Gm₁m₂ / r². Yes, everything attracts everything—even you and Saturn.
For big distances, like satellites, use U = -Gm₁m₂ / r instead of mgh.
Three laws describing orbits: planets move in ellipses, sweep equal areas in equal times, and orbital period² ∝ distance³.
Speed needed to stay in orbit. It balances gravity pulling inward with inertia moving forward.
Minimum speed to break free from gravity with no turning back. No more orbiting—you’re outta here.
It’s like gravity but for charges. Opposites attract, likes repel. Use Coulomb’s Law: F = kq₁q₂ / r².
The electric force between charges depends on the product of charges and the square of the distance between them.
They point away from positive and toward negative. More lines = stronger field.
It’s the ‘electric energy per charge.’ Like gravitational potential, but for electric stuff. Measured in volts.
Lines where electric potential is the same. Moving along one takes no work.
Stores electric energy by separating charges on two plates. More voltage = more stored charge.
An insulating material between capacitor plates that increases its ability to store charge.
Conventional current flows from positive to negative—even though electrons go the other way.
In any loop, the total voltage gained = total voltage dropped. Like energy budgeting for a circuit.
What flows into a junction = what flows out. Charge doesn’t just disappear.
Add them up: R_total = R₁ + R₂ + ... Current is the same through each.
Total resistance goes down. Use 1/R_total = 1/R₁ + 1/R₂ + ... Voltage is the same across each.
A resistor and capacitor together. The capacitor charges gradually over time instead of instantly.
Measures how much magnetic field goes through an area. Changing flux = induced current!
